text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

As someone who started as
a great skeptic of the case

method, I've become
its strongest advocate.

I began teaching at Harvard
Business School in 1996.
I had never seen a case before.

I never thought the case
method would or could work,

that there was
too much to teach.

I, with all my experience, could
bring that to the students.

Wouldn't they want to
learn from me, the expert?

In fact, I learned to
trust the students.

That if I could
write a good case,

the students would come up
with the answers by themselves
and with each other.

I've written well over 100
cases for all these courses.

I think over the
years I've learned

that what makes a good case
is to make them muddled

and make them more
like real life.

If I want to teach the
basic tools for analysis

in buying or valuing real
estate or taxation or investing,
but I'll also have other issues.

I'll have issues of
organizational behavior, issues

of gender, issues of diversity,
of sustainability, of ethics

all woven through every case
to make it like the real world.

What makes it exciting for
a teacher is, I'm learning

and I'm juggling, and I'm
trying to stay in control

when, in fact, you
completely lose control

and you have to go
with the flow and you

have to let the students find
their own progress or dead
ends in any given class.

But it's also challenging and
terrifying but very exciting.

Over the years, I've
learned that classroom
is almost a story unfolding.

And it takes a certain
amount of theater

to get the crescendo and the
a-ha moments at the right time.

And I'll bring in
different elements
that will surprise folks.

So we'll have role-playing,
we'll have videos,

I'll have music,
I'll have guests.

I'll have surprise guests
come in the middle of class.
You can expect the unexpected.

The actors turn
against the audience.

Something happens that's
different to keep the students'

attention so
they'll remember it,

and they'll remember
the learnings.

And that's why it's really a
great intellectual experience

for someone who thinks he, she
knows what's going to happen.
We never do.
And it's always different.

I can teach three classes in
a row using the same case,

and they will be entirely
different classes.

And that's what makes
case method so effective

and such a great tool
for all of us to learn.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
